div.head: Finsbury
div.p: The area known as Finsbury, once part of a great fen outside the city walls, lay within the parish of St Giles without Cripplegate, which stretched across both the city of London and the county of Middlesex. Finsbury, which never became a parish in its own right, consisted of two manors, the first that of the freedom of London, which lay within the city, and the second the lordship of Finsbury, held by a prebend of St Paul’s Cathedral and lying within the county of Middlesex. The lordship was leased by the dean and chapter of St Paul’s to the city from 1315 to 1867, with the recorder acting as steward of the manor. This was where the Fortune playhouse was situated. From 1900 to 1965 Finsbury was a London borough and included the Middlesex parishes of St James and St John, Clerkenwell, St Luke Old Street (separated from St Giles without Cripplegate in 1732), the extra parochial district of the Charterhouse, and the Liberty of Glasshouse Yard. Finsbury Borough later amalgamated with the London Borough of Islington.

div.head: Affidavit in Markham v. Clayton
div.note: This document relates to Gervase Markham's suit to collect money due from thirty-nine people, who had subscribed to Markham's plan to travel on foot from London to Berwick, using only 'an ordinary Leape staffe' to cross water. When he returned, his backers refused to pay, and so Markham sued in the court of Requests.

div.head: Bill of Complaint in Cane v. Wintershall
div.note: These are the depositions taken on behalf of the plaintiffs in the counter-suit by Andrew Cane and other one-time members of the prince of Wales' company who had played at the Fortune about thirty years previously, against Margaret, wife of William Wintershall and daughter of the late Richard Gunnell, manager of the Fortune. The initial suit is at TNA: PRO C10/32/31, where a fuller account of the dispute over a bond for £40 can be found.

msIdentifier.repository: The National Archives: Public Record Office

physDesc.p: parchment; single membrane; 305mm x 457mm; some creasing and rubbing.

div.head: Answers in Cane v. Wintershall
div.note: This case was a dispute over a bond for £80 made in April 1624 between Richard Gunnell, part owner of the Fortune, with six sharers in the prince of Wales' company including Andrew Cane (later de Caine), who were to act only at that playhouse. Gunnell died in 1634, but in 1654 his daughter Margaret, wife of William Wintershall, who was now her mother’s executrix, sued Cane for £40 on the bond. Cane countersued and in February 1654/5 Cane's lawyer took depositions from five witnesses: Ellis Worth, William Hall, John Wright, and Henry Hammerton, all former players, and Edward Cane, Andrew's son (found at TNA: PRO C24/785/53 (pt 1)).

div.head: Interrogatories in Alleyn v. Marten
div.note: This case concerning a tenement called the Chapel at 'Bedlam' in the parish of St Botolph Bishopsgate, London, are useful for clarifying the family background of Edward Alleyn, the theatrical entrepreneur and owner of the Fortune playhouse, and of his wife Margaret.

div.head: Contract by Peter Streete between Philip Henslowe and Edward Alleyn
div.note: A contract made between Philip Henslowe and Edward Alleyn and Peter Street, carpenter, furnishes physical details about the Fortune theatre. Street is commissioned to build a new playhouse on a plot of ground near Golden Lane in the parish of St Giles Cripplegate, according to the criteria laid out in the contract. The description of the projected theatre discusses first the frame, then the stage and tiring house, the windows and lights, the tiling of the frame and staircases, and details of the ceiling and floors. In each particular, the design of the new playhouse is to follow the plan of the Globe, 'saving only that all the principal and main posts of the said frame and stage forward shall be square and wrought plasterwise with carved proportions called satyrs to be placed and set on top of every of the same posts.' Street is to provide the materials at his own 'proper costs and charges' and is to complete the building before 25 July of the same year. Henslowe and Alleyn are to pay Street.

physDesc.p: parchment; single membrane; 442mm x 535mm (355mm x 485mm), dorse written in 2 columns (first column 410mm x 255--80mm, second column 300mm x 190--210mm).

div.head: Bargain and Sale by Daniel Gill and Others to Edward Alleyn
div.note: With the help of Patrick Brewe, Edward Alleyn purchases the freehold of the Fortune property from its owners, Daniel Gill the elder and his two sons, four daughters, and their husbands, for 340 pounds. The property includes twelve tenements and the Fortune playhouse. The contract describes the situation of the tenements, playhouse, and premises, and names the adjoining property owners.

div.head: Assignment by Agnes Henslowe to Gregory Franklin and John Hammond of Leases from Edward Alleyn to Philip Henslowe
div.note: The terms of Philip Henslowe and Edward Alleyn's agreement of 4 April 1601 over the Fortune property are recorded in a later document of 15 February 1615/16, an unexecuted assignment of Henslowe's leases by his widow, Agnes. Alleyn leased Henslowe a moiety of the playhouse and 'a certain plot of ground' on which the playhouse was built. Henslowe was also to receive one-half of the profits of the playhouse. The items excepted from the agreement were 'the allowance and part of the company which for the time being shall play there' and the grounds and properties adjoining the playhouse.

physDesc.p: parchment; single membrane; 550mm x 714mm (495mm x 670mm); parchment tags for 3 seals not attached.

div.head: Certificate of Rents Due to Dulwich College
div.note: Because of the closure of the playhouses due to plague in 1636, the tenants of the Fortune playhouse had fallen into arrears with their annual rent of £128 5s 4d. The College therefore commenced a suit in Chancery (see the Chancery Bill Regarding Non-Payment of Rents, DCA: MS I, Article 115). For an MS digital image see the Henslowe-Alleyn Digitisation Project .

div.head: Commissary Court Probate and Admission Acts
div.note: Peter Street was the master carpenter who demolished the Theatre at Shoreditch, built the Globe in Southwark, and then later the Fortune in Golding Lane. At the time of his death he was carpenter to Bridewell Hospital, to which position his son John was elected on 13 May (GL: MS 33011/5, f 347). 'Peter Streat Carpenter' was buried at St Bride, Fleet Street, on 13 May 1609 (GL: MS 06538, Burials).

div.head: Letter of William Bird to Edward Alleyn
div.note: This letter is undated but is placed around this date in Warner's Catalogue, p 49. William Birde alias Bourne, a player known from 1597 and who died in 1624, was one of the lessees of the Fortune in 1618 in which John Russell is also mentioned as a tenant (DCA: Muniment 56). Russell was probably a relation of Agnes Henslowe for on 8 August 1619 Alleyn paid him a legacy due from her (DCA: MS IX). The letter throws an interesting light on the management of the company and the role of the gatherer. For an MS digital image see the Henslowe-Alleyn Digitisation Project .

div.head: Letter from William Wilson to Edward Alleyn
div.note: This letter was offered for sale by the London booksellers Myers and Company in its Illustrated Catalogue of Rare Books, 1918, as an autograph letter, attributed as 'from one of the actors of Shakespeare's Company.' James Quincy Adams took down a transcription from two photographic facsimiles, and this is now copied out here. The sale catalogue notes that William Wilson and Dorothy Seare were married at St Saviour's, Southwark, on Sunday, 2 November 1617, which gives dates for the letter, but efforts to trace it have failed. The letter was endorsed: 'To my most deare & especeall good frend mr. Edward Alleyn at Dulwich deliverd these.'
div.bibl: Adams, James Quincy. 'An "Hitherto Unknown" Actor of Shakespeare's Troupe?' Modern Language Notes 34 (1919), 46--8.

div.head: Administration Grant of Richard Gunnell’s Will
div.note: Richard Gunnell (fl. 1613--34) was a player with Palsgrave's men 1613--22. He also wrote several plays (of which none survive) for the company at the second Fortune, in which he held a full share and of which he acted as manager. In 1628 he and William Blagrave built the Salisbury Court theatre, near Fleet Street. Richard Gunnell, of the parish of St Giles without Cripplegate, gentleman, was accused of recusancy in January 1627/8 and July 1629 (LMA: MJ/SR/0680/51 and 0703/20). He was buried at St Bride's on 7 October 1634 (but was not the eponymous man buried at St Giles Cripplegate on 22 January 1629/30). TNA: PRO PROB 6/15 was only available to view on microfilm.

div.head: John Shauncke's Will
div.note: John Shauncke (1616--55) was possibly the actor son of king's man John Shank (d. 1635). He was with the Red Bull provincial company in 1635, at the Fortune playhouse in 1640, and legatee of his father and of Richard Benfield (d. 1639). In February 1639/40 his wife sued for alimony in the High Court for Causes Ecclesiastical, when the 'Steward' of the Fortune playhouse was to provide financial evidence from his 'booke of shares' for an allotment out of her husband’s earnings (TNA: PRO SP16/434, ff 127 and 137v). Administration was granted 10 September 1656 to Henry Hasard, with exhibition of inventory (TNA: PRO PROB 8/50, f 267v). Shauncke was not the man buried at St Giles in the Fields in October 1641, since 'one Shanks a player' deserted the Parliamentary forces in October 1642. That was possibly this testator. (See Edwin Nungezer, A Dictionary of Actors (London, 1929), 320--1; Gerald Eades Bentley, The Jacobean and Caroline Stage, vol 2 (Oxford, 1966), 567--9; and E.A.J. Honigmann and Susan Brock, Playhouse Wills, 1558—1642 (Manchester and New York, 1993), 208--9).

div.head: Fennor's Defence
div.note: John Taylor (1578--1653), citizen and waterman of London, was known as the Water Poet. He had challenged William Fennor, in the latter's words: 'the Gentleman-like Sculler at the Hope on the Banke-side, at a friends house of mine, acquainted me with his Proiect; which was as followeth: That hee the said Taylor had studied such seuerall Hu-mors in Prose, as neuer were the like before: (which indeede fell out true, to his shame) wherein hee would haue me ioyne; hee to play a Scene in Prose, and I to answere him in Uerse' (sigs A3--A3v). Although he had 1,000 bills printed to publicize the meeting, to be held on 7 October, Fennor failed to show, writing in his defence that his father had called him home to Warwickshire, so Taylor penned his 'Revenge.' Fennor added that he had at one time challenged one Kendall to a similar contest, but he in his turn had not appeared. This was either the actor William Kendall, or perhaps Timothy Kendall, a university-educated wit (see Tiffany Stern, Documents of Performance in Early Modern England (Cambridge, 2009), 249).
div.bibl:
FENNORS
DEFENCE:
Or,
I am your first Man.
VVherein the VVater-man,
IOHN TAYLOR, is dasht, sowst, and finally
fallen into the Thames: With his slanderous
Taxations, base Imputations, scandalous Accu-
sations, and foule Abhominations, against his
Maiesties Ryming Poet: who hath An-
swered him without Vexations, or
trembling Recantations.
The Reason of my no meeting at the
Hope with Taylor, is truly demonstrated in
the Induction to the Iudger.
Thy hastie Gallop my milde Muse shall checke,
That if thou sit not sure, will breake thy necke.

div.head: Lease from Philip Henslowe and Edward Alleyn to Thomas Downton
div.note: Edward Alleyn and Philip Henslowe drew up a contract which, if executed, would grant Thomas Dowton, an actor in the company, a share in the profits of the playhouse. The term of the contract was for thirteen years, and Dowton was to pay for his share 27 pounds 10s in cash up front, and thereafter 10s a year. The actor would receive 'one-eight part of a fourth' of the total playhouse profits, and in return assume responsibility for a proportionate share of the playhouse expenses. Dowton would be bound to continue playing at the Fortune, and only at the Fortune, for the stipulated term. He would not be allowed to transfer his share to another party.

physDesc.p: parchment; single membrane; 475mm x 500mm (315mm x 460mm).

For an MS digital image see the Henslowe-Alleyn Digitisation Project .

div.head: Lease from Edward Alleyn to Edward Juby and Others
div.note: On 31 October 1618, Edward Alleyn drew up a lease granting use of the Fortune to ten of the Palsgrave's men: Edward Juby, William Bird (alias Bourne), Frank Grace, Richard Gunnell, Charles Massey, William Stratford, William Cartwright, Richard Price, William Parr, and Richard Fowler. The term of the lease was for thirty-one years, beginning 29 September 1618, and the rent was 200 pounds a year, as well as two roundlets of wine, 'the one sack and the other claret, of 10s apiece price, to be delivered at the feast of Christmas yearly.' The leaseholders were not to alter the playhouse in any way, or to use it to any other purpose.

div.head: Surveyors' Report on State of the Playhouse
div.note: This 1656 survey of the playhouse describes its now ruinous state some thirty years after the second Fortune had been rebuilt in brick. A contemporary copy is now preserved in BL: MS Egerton 2623, f 32. The surveyors also mention other tenements in Whitecross Street and Golding Lane, whose descriptions have not been here transcribed, and proposed that twenty-three tenements should be constructed on the ground. In 1650, however, the parish return of St Giles without Cripplegate could say that as the parishioners were unable to build a place of worship for themselves, they proposed that the large building known as the Fortune playhouse should be set aside for that purpose. This application does not appear to have been put into effect (BL: Additional MS 24461, f 116). Between March 1659/60 and July 1662 various legal documents were put in hand for the sale of the materials and site of the Fortune (where the playhouse was described as 'soe ruinous yat parte thereof is already fallen downe') and the granting of a building lease to William Beavan (DCA: MS I, Articles 125--34). In February 1660/1 the Mercurius Politicus contained an advertisement for letting the ground where the now demolished Fortune playhouse had once stood. For an MS digital image see the Henslowe-Alleyn Digitisation Project .
